title: DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE
author: Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 1
filename: 161 - The Butcher of Brisbane - Marc Platt_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
SCENE 1. INT. COURTROOM (PEKING, 5001 AD)
FX: COURTROOM AMBIENCE.
(CALLING) All rise for the Supreme Minister of Justice, the Honourable Magnus Greel.
FX: EVERYONE STANDS.
(WALKING IN) Good morning.
FX: HE TAKES HIS PLACE.
This session of the Star Chamber is now resumed.
Next prisoner. One Zero Zero, Seven Four Two. Stand forward.
FX: GREEL SHUFFLES PAPERS WHILE RAGNAR TAKES STAND. IT’S
STANDARD PROCEDURE TO BE GOT THROUGH BEFORE LUNCH.
Ragnar Crezzen, you are found guilty of the attempted murder of a government official of the Supreme Alliance of Eastern States.
(QUIETLY) People have to know.
Quiet.
The subversive actions of Earth Free Media have imperilled the security of the Alliance. Such crimes are punishable by termination.
In your experiment camps, Greel? In the Dead Zone? How many victims now?
Be quiet.
How many others have you sent to the time chambers?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 3
FX: RAGNAR GASPS AS A GUARD STRIKES HIM.
But... at this time of disturbance and unrest, let us be seen to be lenient. The death sentence is reprieved. Ragnar Crezzen, you will be transported for life to a work group in the Outer Colonies.
But that’s not what happens, is it? That’s just for show, for the official bulletins. I know my future. It’s already happened!
Take him down.
You’re the Butcher, Greel! (LED AWAY BY GUARDS, STRUGGLING) One day you’1ll drown in your victims’ blood!
(CALLING) Next prisoner. Stand forward.
(OUTSIDE) You’re the Butcher!
FX: A DOOR SLAMS SHUT.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 4
SCENE 2. INT. FINDECKER’S LAB
FX: ANOTHER DOOR CLANKS OPEN. FOOTSTEPS AS RAGNAR IS LED IN.
Delivery of Prisoner One Zero Zero, Seven Four Two.
(COLD, SLIGHTLY THROATY ALIEN, PRECISE AND FAST) Place him in the projection chamber.
(SHOCKED) Findecker! It’s you... !
How fascinating. The human propensity for distress seems boundless and so self-indulgent. Restrain him.
FX: ELECTRONIC BOLTS SNAP ACROSS. RAGNAR GASPS IN PAIN. GUARD
EXITS, DOOR CLANKS SHUT THROUGH:
Don’t struggle, please. Your suffering will be quite extensive enough without compounding your injury.
(HALF CHOKED) I came to find you. I was going to kill you. For Sasha’s sake!
Sasha? Oh, yes, of course. (WITH RELISH) Sasha. I remember...
FX: CONSULTS PAPERS.
. Prisoner “One Zero Zero, Seven Four Two” - because that’s all you are now. It’s too late for vengeance, I’m afraid.
I knew that.
But you’re still an invaluable part of my research. So thank you, Ragnar Crezzen. Your circle is complete.
FX: THE PROJECTION CHAMBER STARTS TO THROB WITH POWER.
SCREAMS
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 5
SCENE 3. INT. TARDIS — TEGAN & NYSSA’S BEDROOM
Camel racing? What are camels?
Big... lopey.. sort of like a double-decker horse with a hump.
(AMUSED) I see.
And if the Doctor gets it right, we might be home in time for shearing.
That sounds ominous. Do the camels object?
Now that would be worth seeing. No. It’s the sheep that get sheared. For wool. On my Dad’s station outside Toowoomba.
Ah, that explains it. Natural fibre for clothing.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Actually, Nyssa, camel wool is used by the Bedouin to keep out the heat. Can I come in?
Have you been earwigging?
Not from choice. You’re so excited, I could hear you from halfway down the corridor.
So could we do it, do you think? Be home in time for shearing?
Which would be...?
Early June.
Well, I’ll try.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 6
Tell you what. Turlough shearing a bolshy Merino. That’s something I’d pay to see!
(TO DOCTOR) She’s excited.
I can tell.
It’ll be great. And then we can drive down to Brizzie.
That’s Brisbane, of course.
There’s a whole load of places I’m taking you. It’s where I went to school.
Excellent. I look forward to it.
(APPROACHING) Doctor?
Turlough. Come in. Tegan’s planning our itinerary.
(TO TURLOUGH) Fancy a spot of sheep-shearing?
Doctor, I think you should come and look at the console. It’s making... “juddering” noises.
Juddering?
Like when a car’s about to stall?
You'd better show me. (FX: THEY DEPART.)
Oh, no. Not now.
I don’t believe it. Do you think, just for once, he could fly this old crate properly?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 4. INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: ENGINES JUDDERING AS TURLOUGH AND DOCTOR WALK IN BRISKLY
There! See what I mean?
(AT CONSOLE) I don’t like the sound of that. Something’s thrown the drive system out of phase.
FX: DOCTOR FLICKING SWITCHES
The TARDIS certainly picks its moments, doesn’t it?
Not always. We seem to have hit a field of turbulence in the vortex.
FX: CONSOLE BURRS
See that? The quantum pressure outside’s dropping like a stone.
(WALKING IN, FOLLOWED BY TEGAN) What’s happening?
FX: THE JUDDERING INCREASES.
I might have known it. Batten down the hatches!
Just a bit choppy out there, that’s all. Nothing to worry about.
Oh, yeah? Sounds like engine trouble to me.
(TO DOCTOR) Is there somewhere we can put down?
Sooner rather than later, preferably?
FX: A BLADE OF ENERGY APPEARS, CUTTING THROUGH THE CONSOLE
ROOM.
Look out!
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 8
What is it?
Get away from that, all of you!
It’s like a curtain of light!
I said, keep clear!
FX: AND THEN TIME STARTS TO SPLINTER, ECHOING AND JUMBLING
ITSELF BACK AT THEM.
Sooner rather than later preferably.
Sounds like engine trouble to me.
What’s happening?!
Is there somewhere we can put down?
Some sort of energy beam! It’s slicing the ship in two!
It’s splintering reality! Nyssa, Turlough — come around to this side of the console!
Nothing to worry about.
We can’t!
Sounds like engine trouble to me.
Nyssa! Hold on to me!
Is there somewhere we can put down?
FX: REPEAT AND OVERLAY IN A JUDDERING TANGLE. THROUGH THIS:
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 9
(FURTHER AWAY) We’re cut off! Doctor!
Where are you?! Nyssa!!!
(FURTHER AWAY) Nyssa! Over here!
Nyssa! Turlough! Come towards my voice!
(FAR OFF) Doctor! Help me!
Reach out, Nyssa! Reach out and take my hand!
NYSSA & TURLOUGH (FADING AWAY) Doctov...!
FX: AND WITH AN INCOMING WHOOSH, REALITY WHUMPS BACK INTO
EXISTENCE. NORMAL TARDIS HUM.
(SHAKEN) Nyssa? Turlough? (BEAT) Doctor, they’ve gone!
I know.
FX: HE CLAMBERS UP AND STARTS BLIPPING THE CONTROLS.
Reality was breached. That energy beam was carving up the ship’s dimensions.
Breached? (SCARED) What about Nyssa and Turlough?
(GRAVELY) Tegan... they may have been torn out of the TARDIS’s internal continuum.
But we were in flight. They could be anywhere. They could even be... [dead. ]
First we must check the ship’s integrity. And before you ask, Tegan, I don’t know where they are. Or when. Or what that energy beam was. But I promise you, we’re going to find out.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 10
SCENE 5: EXT. SNOWY MOUNTAINSIDE (BHUTAN)
FX: FADE UP. THE WIND MOANS. IT’S BITTERLY COLD. NYSSA AND
TURLOUGH’S FOOTSTEPS CRUNCH IN THE SNOW. THEY ARE LOST AND SHIVERING. CONVERSATIONS ARE BREATHLESS AND GASPING.
Turlough. How much further?
As far as the trees. We can shelter there.
Not too far. For when the Doctor comes looking for us.
If the TARDIS is still in one piece. (BEAT) Sorry. But we have to reach cover.
FX: THEY SCRUNCH ONWARD.
Turlough? I can’t feel my fingers.
Not far now. Keep going. The snow’s not so deep here.
FX: THEY CRUNCH ON.
When you stop shivering. That’s when you’re in trouble.
That’s good to know. Nearly there.
Wait.
No, keep going.
There’s something... over there. Lying in the snow.
It’s just a rock. We need to get under shelter.
I have to be sure.
Please come on.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL)
We can’t... we can’t just leave someone.
FX: SHE TRUDGES OFF.
Nyssa, come back... Nyssa!
FX: THE WIND MOANS.
Page 11
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 12
SCENE 6: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: THE DOCTOR BLIPPING CONTROLS.
(ANGRY) They could be anywhere? I thought they were out in the Time Vortex!
That’s one possibility.
Then can’t we circle back to where they went over the side, or something?
Unfortunately it doesn’t work like that. (REACHING ACROSS) Excuse me.
sorry.
FX: HE BLIPS A CONTROL.
The Vortex is endlessly shifting. There’s no constant. Nowhere
to throw a lifebelt. Anyway, the incursion of that energy beam means they could have been thrown directly into the continuum.
Oh. But that’s good, right? Somewhere solid we can reach.
Perhaps.
FX: BLIP BLEEP.
Or not. Come on... respond!
FX: HE THUMPS THE CONSOLE. BLEEP.
But that takes us back to “could be anywhere”. They could be
dead by now!
Tegan, I’m doing my best.
sorry.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 13
The energy beam left residues in the ship. And if we can locate its source...
You’re already trying that, aren’t you?
Amongst other things.
FX: PING.
Ah... intriguing.
Well?
The beam was composed of zygma energy.
This is me you’re talking to.

It’s a notoriously tricky source of radiation. The double nexus particle — one half is in the solid universe, but its mirror nucleus exists outside time and space altogether. It’s often mistaken as a vital component of time travel.
But if they’re linked... couldn’t we latch onto the half that zapped us.. the bit in the vortex...
. and piggyback into the continuum? Yes, that’s what I was hoping.
And will it get Nyssa and Turlough back?
I’m trying, Tegan. That’s all I can do.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 14
SCENE 7: EXT. SNOWY MOUNTAINSIDE (BHUTAN)
FX: BLIZZARD AS BEFORE.
(APPROACHING FROM OFF) Nyssa, hang on.
It’s a woman.
Be careful.
She’s cut a furrow right through the snow. As if she’d been shot out of something.
She can’t have survived.
No. She’s frozen solid. I’m sorry.
Ugh... her face. She’s.. withered.
Desiccated.
(BEAT) Well... sorry and everything, but we need these.
FX: HE TUGS AT THE CLOTHES.
What are you doing?
Clothes. We need them.
(SPOTTING SOMETHING SCARY) Turlough...
I’m being practical, Nyssa. We’1ll both be joining her if we don’t help ourselves.
No. I meant over there. Another body.
What?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 15
And more of them that way.
Where have we landed up? In some sort of graveyard?
I don’t know.
(RETURNING TO BODY) Come on. We need these clothes.
FX: A FLASH OF SOUND — HALF LIGHTNING, HALF THE BEAM THAT
SCOURGED THE TARDIS.
Look out!
FX: ANOTHER BODY WHOOSHES INTO THE SNOW.
Another one. They’re dumping them here.
The air opened up and he just... fell through.
DISTANT) (MOANS
He’s still alive. Come on.
FX: THEY CRUNCH FORWARD TO WHERE RAGNAR LIES. TEN MINUTES AGO,
HE WAS YOUNG RAGNAR. THEN HE WAS THROWN THREE YEARS BACK IN TIME AND THE SHOCK HAS REDUCED HIM TO A HUSK.
(GROANS. IN PAIN. EVERY WORD A CROAKED EFFORT) There you are.
Are you hurt? What happened? Where did you come from?
I knew you’d be here. Waiting.
Waiting?
I’m Nyssa and he’s...
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 16
Turlough.
What?
(WINCES) Everything goes round.
How can you know us? Who are you?
It’s three years ago, isn’t it? He’s thrown me back three years.
He’s rambling.
(SHOCKED) My hands... What’s he done to me? That monster Findecker. What about my face? How old do I look? How old?!
(AWKWARD) You’re not exactly young.
(GROANS) I was twenty-three. He stole my future.
We can’t stay out in the open. The trees aren’t far.
Twenty three... that’s all...
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 17
SCENE 8. INT. TARDIS -— CONTROL ROOM
FX: SEVERAL PINGS FROM THE CONSOLE.
That’s it!
You found the source of the Zygma beam?
Just waiting for the co-ordinates. But if we’re going to find Nyssa and Turlough, we’ll need to know where it was directed.
Directed? Like a weapon?
I don’t think we were under fire. That’s not what Zygma radiation’s used for.
Well, what then? Come on. Don’t clam up on me now.
FX: PING.
Ah. The co-ordinates.
You’re changing the subject.
(OMINOUS) It’s what I was afraid of. Earth. In the fifty-first century.
Strewth, that’s a long haul. But at least the air will be breathable... won’t it?
(LYING) Yes, yes. It’1ll be fine.
Now you’re scaring me. What’s wrong?
Let’s just find Nyssa and Turlough, shall we? The sooner the better.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 18
SCENE 9: EXT. SNOWY MOUNTAINSIDE (BHUTAN)
FX: WIND MOANS. BRANCHES PUSHED ASIDE AS TURLOUGH AND NYSSA
CARRY RAGNAR UNDER THE TREES.
(EFFORT, HAULING RAGNAR) We’1ll be out of the wind under the trees.
(EFFORT) It’ll just take longer for us to freeze.
GROANS AS THEY LAY HIM DOWN
Careful.
He’s heavy.
FX: DISTANT CRACK OF ZYGMA LIGHTNING. ANOTHER BODY SCREAMS DOWN
AND WHUMPFS INTO THE SNOW. THEN ANOTHER.
More of them. More people.
More bodies. They’re raining down out there.
(EXHAUSTED WHISPER) Findecker’s having a busy day.
Who’s Findecker?
FX: ZYGMA LIGHTNING AND BODIES FALLING CONTINUE SPORADICALLY.
We can’t help all of them.
No-one survives the experiments. Not for long.
But who did this to you? Where did you come from?
Hell. I came from Hell. The darkest of futures. All of us here on the mountain. But it’1ll be better, now you’re here. (COUGHS)
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 19
You’re from the future?
FX: CRACK OF ZYGMA LIGHTNING AND WHUMPF OF A BODY LANDING
NEARBY.
They’re getting closer. Maybe we should move.
No. There’s a tag on my wrist. A beacon.
Is someone coming? Will they rescue us too?
But you never had tags, did you? That’s why you’re important. Nyssa and Turlough. Ugh...
He’s injured. He needs medication!
(WEAKENING) Tell Sasha, when she gets here...
Sasha?
Tell her you don’t have tags. (WINCES) You don’t even exist.
But we don’t understand. We don’t belong here.
No-one knows you. That’s good. Sasha will understand. You’re so brave, Nyssa. Magnus Greel...
Magnus who?
Uh... (FADING) I wanted to see Sasha one last time. Before she dies, too. But she was always hopeless at hitting deadlines...
FX: ONE, THEN TWO MORE DISTANT CRACKS OF LIGHTNING AND BODIES
FALLING.
He’s gone.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 20
We didn’t even know his name.
FX: ELECTRIC BURR OF AN APPROACHING JET SLEDGE.
Someone’s coming. Get down!
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 21
SCENE 10. EXT. WASTELAND (FUTURE BRISBANE)
FX: NIGHTTIME INSECTS. TARDIS MATERIALISES. DOOR OPENS.
(STEPPING OUT) Not a lot here, is there? Unless you like ruins.
FX: THE DOCTOR’S TRACKER BURRS.
The source of the Zygma energy must be over the next ridge.
FX: SHUTS DOOR) There’s a way up through there. (WALKS
(FOLLOWING) It’s too creepy — (SLIPS IN MUD) Aah!
(HELPING HER UP) Careful.
Flaming mud! Why isn’t the fifty-first century all space cities and monorails?
That would have been the thirty-first. Things moved on.
FX: THEY SET OFF UP SLIPPERY SLOPE.
Mainly backwards.
That’s truer than you think. It’s another Ice Age.
Is it? It’s not snowing here.
Maybe not. But the snowfields cover all of Europe and North America, and reach up as far as Tasmania in the south.
That’s not a lot of room left.
There’s been a mass exodus to the colonies. Earth’s been gutted of its resources anyway. It’s just a factory now, processing material from elsewhere.
You know what’s going on, don’t you? You’re just not telling, as usual. Where is this, exactly?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 22
Tricky bit here. Take my hand.
Got it. Thanks.
No, I just don’t like Zygma energy.
Did that cause all this?
It’s not easy to explain.
Nyssa would tell me.. if she was here.
(SIGHING) The Zygma beam is the product of a crude exercise in time travel experimentation, for which this century is justly notorious. Nearly at the top.
Did you do “future” lessons at school too? As well as history?
Oh, you wouldn’t believe.
FX: THEY STOP CLIMBING.
Here we are. That’s better. You can see the river.
But what a wreck. What happened to the city? Was there a war?
I told you. This century is turbulent.
Hang on. I know this place. The shape of the land... it’s familiar. Down there. That wrecked building... That’s the old Windmill!
Tegan...
We’re on Spring Hill. These ruins... this was Brisbane!
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 23
SCENE 11. EXT. BARRACKS
(THE DORMITORY OF FINDECKER’S DOG TROOPERS: CYBORG SOLDIERS WITH THE GRUFF INSTINCTS OF WILD DINGOES )
(PADDING IN, SHOUTING) Hi! You lot! Stir yourselves!
GRUMBLE IN THEIR BASKETS
Come one! Out of your baskets! (SNIFFS) You get that? Hurr... Clean... nice... close by. (GROWLS) Niffs like people. Big Chiefy won’t like that.
GROWL
Better fetch ‘em in, eh? Come on! Turn out the barracks. You boys need a run. Long time since we ‘ad fresh meat for dinner.
RUSH OUT, YELPING
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 12: EXT. SNOWY MOUNTAINSIDE (BHUTAN)
FX: THE SLEDGE ARRIVES AND STOPS. DOOR OPENS. SASHA DIALFA, EFM
REPORTER, CLIMBS OUT INTO THE SNOW AND CRUNCHES TOWARDS THEM.
Alright, you two. You don’t have to hide.
(SLIGHTLY OFF, EMERGING FROM UNDERGROWTH) Please. Can you help us? So many people need help here.
You must be frozen. Here. I’ve got thermal blankets.
FX: SHE PASSES BLANKETS OVER.
Thank you.
FX: SASHA CLICKS A COMM DEVICE.
cc? It’s Sasha. It’s like a massacre, but I’ve got two survivors.
FX: CLICKS OFF COMMS.
Sasha Dialfa, Earth Free Media. Are you hurt? Can you tell me where you came from? Look, I’d like to interview you.
You’re Sasha?
There’s someone here who told us to expect you.
Me?
He’s here. I’m sorry.
FX: PUSHING BRANCHES BACK.
We tried to help him, but...
I’m sorry, I don’t - (STUNNED) Oh, my — Ragnar! His face. He’s so old. What happened?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 25
FX: ZYGMA LIGHTNING CRACKS REPEATEDLY. MORE BODIES ARE
WHOOSHING DOWN THROUGHOUT THE SCENE.
He said he came from the future.
Three years in the future.
He did it. He proved it. The idiot killed himself to prove it!
I’m sorry.
(CRYING) The victims are coming from the future. Oh, heavens.
FX: CLICKS COMM
CC? I’ve got Ragnar here. He’s dead.
He said you’d help us.
Turlough...
Yes. (COMPOSING HERSELF) Yes, I’m sorry. You fell through too? Out of the sky?
No. We don’t know who these people are.
They started appearing weeks ago. Thousands of bodies. The whole mountain’s knee deep. You’re lucky it’s been snowing.
But we’re lost too. Your friend said we should tell you.
Ragnar? What did he say?
That we had no “tags.”
(AMAZED) No tags?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 26
He said we don’t exist. That you’d understand.
He seemed to think we were important.
No tags.
FX: CLICKS COMM.
CC? I’m bringing in a couple of unknowns. Run a check, will
you? (TO NYSSA & TURLOUGH) Sorry. What did you say your names were again?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 13. EXT. WASTELAND (FUTURE BRISBANE)
FX: AS BEFORE.
(STUNNED) Brisbane...
(GENTLE) It wasn’t deliberate, Tegan. I had to know where that energy beam came from.
You expect me to believe that? I feel sick.
I’m sorry. Truly sorry.
This wasteland is where I grew up!
It’s a long way in the future.
It’s horrible. What happened here? How many people died?
I don’t know.
You always know. You always know the horrible things!
I try to put them right.
But it doesn’t stop them from happening, does it?!
Sometimes. Sometimes it does. (BEAT) Tegan. Do you want to go back?
(DETERMINED) No. No, we have to find Nyssa and Turlough. It’s just...
I know. You’ve had a terrible shock.
Please. Take your readings. We have to get on.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 28
FX: DOCTOR’S TRACKER BURRS.
Down the hill, then.
FX: THEY SET OFF.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 14: INT. SPACE STATION
(INTO COMMS) This is breaking news. Activity detected in the Brisbane Dead Zone. Standby Editorial Team Three.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
(NERVOUS) Ragnar?
(EXCITED) Sasha. Did you get that? Activity detected in the Brisbane Dead Zone!
We need to talk.
It’s started. Three years we’ve waited for this. The Doctor arrives at last!
Look... this story. I want you to stand down.
(AMUSED) Me? You’re joking. This is it.. the home run!
For your own sake.
(ANNOYED) Scared I’1l get myself killed? I’m not a ten-year- old. What really happened, when you first met Nyssa?
This isn’t the time.
You always clam up. You’1l have to tell me one day.
I can’t explain. Please, Ragnar! Just stand down.
FX: KLAXON BLARES.
This is it, then. We’re going in. Both of us.
(DEFEATED) Ragnar, please... be careful.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 15: EXT. WASTELAND (FUTURE BRISBANE)
FX: DISTANT MOANING LIKE A SLOWED-DOWN BABY.
(STOPS WALKING) What was that? Doctor? Don’t say there’s wild animals here.
Nothing dangerous, I’m sure.
FX: MOANING GETTING CLOSER.
Then what’s that? It’s coming from [over there]
(PULLING HER ASIDE) Get down.
FX: THEY CROUCH. CREATURE SCUFFLES INTO VIEW, GURGLES.
(MUTTER) What is it?
Like some sort of troll. Do you have those in Australia?
More like a gigantic baby. And no we do not!
Then it’s a mutation.
That big? A mutation of what?
Not all mutants are deleterious.
FX: CREATURE SNARLS AS IT APPROACHES.
However...
It’s seen us!
Its features are twisted; the sort of protein distortion caused by Zygma radiation. We’1ll need a branch to fend it off.
A small tree wouldn’t hold that thing back. Come on! Please!
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 31
Where did I put those keys? (SLAPPING POCKETS) Must be somewhere. Ah...
Doctor, no!
Here. Over here. See these?
FX: HE JANGLES THE KEYS. THE TROLL BABY COOS IN SURPRISE.
Like them? Yes? I thought you would.
Those aren’t the TARDIS keys?
Just uncut spares. (TO TROLL) Yes, pretty, aren’t they?
So now what?
He’s probably in pain. I need to examine him.
Look out!
FX: TROLL LUNGES.
Ah... Dropped them.
FX: TROLL GETTING ANGRY.
Here. I’ve got them.
Tegan, get back!
FX: TROLL SNARLS, STRIKES TEGAN.
CRIES OUT
Tegan!
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 32
FX: WHIZZ AND FIZZ OF A FLARE GOING OFF. THE TROLL CRIES OUT
AND BACKS OFF.
(OFF) Secure the circle! See it off!
FX: SOLDIERS GET IN POSITION. TROLL FLEES.
The mutant’s retreating. Tegan? Are you alright?
How do you think I am? (BEAT) Who are this lot?
Security forces, by the look of them. I’1l handle it.
(APPROACHING) Doctor? Tegan? Sasha Dialfa, Earth Free Media.
The Press?
You know us?
We have to get you out of here now. Ragnar?
Please put these wristbands on.
I don’t think so. Stay by me, Tegan.
You’re coming with us!
Yes, thank you for your offer, but that sort of bossy behaviour only makes me dig my heels in.
This area isn’t safe.
Really. That mutant creature we saw — it used to be human, didn? = at?
Human? !

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 12: EXT. SNOWY MOUNTAINSIDE (BHUTAN)
DOCTOR WHO: REPORTER, CLIMBS OUT INTO THE SNOW AND CRUNCHES TOWARDS THEM.
SASHA: Alright, you two. You don’t have to hide.
NYSSA: (SLIGHTLY OFF, EMERGING FROM UNDERGROWTH) Please. Can you help us? So many people need help here.
SASHA: You must be frozen. Here. I’ve got thermal blankets.
TURLOUGH: Thank you.
SASHA: cc? It’s Sasha. It’s like a massacre, but I’ve got two survivors.
SASHA: Sasha Dialfa, Earth Free Media. Are you hurt? Can you tell me where you came from? Look, I’d like to interview you.
NYSSA: You’re Sasha?
TURLOUGH: There’s someone here who told us to expect you.
SASHA: Me?
NYSSA: He’s here. I’m sorry.
TURLOUGH: We tried to help him, but...
SASHA: I’m sorry, I don’t - (STUNNED) Oh, my — Ragnar! His face. He’s so old. What happened?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 25
DOCTOR WHO: WHOOSHING DOWN THROUGHOUT THE SCENE.
NYSSA: He said he came from the future.
TURLOUGH: Three years in the future.
SASHA: He did it. He proved it. The idiot killed himself to prove it!
NYSSA: I’m sorry.
SASHA: (CRYING) The victims are coming from the future. Oh, heavens.
SASHA: CC? I’ve got Ragnar here. He’s dead.
TURLOUGH: He said you’d help us.
NYSSA: Turlough...
SASHA: Yes. (COMPOSING HERSELF) Yes, I’m sorry. You fell through too? Out of the sky?
TURLOUGH: No. We don’t know who these people are.
SASHA: They started appearing weeks ago. Thousands of bodies. The whole mountain’s knee deep. You’re lucky it’s been snowing.
NYSSA: But we’re lost too. Your friend said we should tell you.
SASHA: Ragnar? What did he say?
NYSSA: That we had no “tags.”
SASHA: (AMAZED) No tags?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 26
TURLOUGH: He said we don’t exist. That you’d understand.
NYSSA: He seemed to think we were important.
SASHA: No tags.
SASHA: CC? I’m bringing in a couple of unknowns. Run a check, will
SASHA: you? (TO NYSSA & TURLOUGH) Sorry. What did you say your names were again?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 27
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 13. EXT. WASTELAND (FUTURE BRISBANE)
TEGAN: (STUNNED) Brisbane...
DOCTOR: (GENTLE) It wasn’t deliberate, Tegan. I had to know where that energy beam came from.
TEGAN: You expect me to believe that? I feel sick.
DOCTOR: I’m sorry. Truly sorry.
TEGAN: This wasteland is where I grew up!
DOCTOR: It’s a long way in the future.
TEGAN: It’s horrible. What happened here? How many people died?
DOCTOR: I don’t know.
TEGAN: You always know. You always know the horrible things!
DOCTOR: I try to put them right.
TEGAN: But it doesn’t stop them from happening, does it?!
DOCTOR: Sometimes. Sometimes it does. (BEAT) Tegan. Do you want to go back?
TEGAN: (DETERMINED) No. No, we have to find Nyssa and Turlough. It’s just...
DOCTOR: I know. You’ve had a terrible shock.
TEGAN: Please. Take your readings. We have to get on.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 28
DOCTOR: Down the hill, then.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 29
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 14: INT. SPACE STATION
RAGNAR: (INTO COMMS) This is breaking news. Activity detected in the Brisbane Dead Zone. Standby Editorial Team Three.
SASHA: (NERVOUS) Ragnar?
RAGNAR: (EXCITED) Sasha. Did you get that? Activity detected in the Brisbane Dead Zone!
SASHA: We need to talk.
RAGNAR: It’s started. Three years we’ve waited for this. The Doctor arrives at last!
SASHA: Look... this story. I want you to stand down.
RAGNAR: (AMUSED) Me? You’re joking. This is it.. the home run!
SASHA: For your own sake.
RAGNAR: (ANNOYED) Scared I’1l get myself killed? I’m not a ten-year- old. What really happened, when you first met Nyssa?
SASHA: This isn’t the time.
RAGNAR: You always clam up. You’1l have to tell me one day.
SASHA: I can’t explain. Please, Ragnar! Just stand down.
RAGNAR: This is it, then. We’re going in. Both of us.
SASHA: (DEFEATED) Ragnar, please... be careful.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 30
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 15: EXT. WASTELAND (FUTURE BRISBANE)
TEGAN: (STOPS WALKING) What was that? Doctor? Don’t say there’s wild animals here.
DOCTOR: Nothing dangerous, I’m sure.
TEGAN: Then what’s that? It’s coming from [over there]
DOCTOR: (PULLING HER ASIDE) Get down.
TEGAN: (MUTTER) What is it?
DOCTOR: Like some sort of troll. Do you have those in Australia?
TEGAN: More like a gigantic baby. And no we do not!
DOCTOR: Then it’s a mutation.
TEGAN: That big? A mutation of what?
DOCTOR: Not all mutants are deleterious.
DOCTOR: However...
TEGAN: It’s seen us!
DOCTOR: Its features are twisted; the sort of protein distortion caused by Zygma radiation. We’1ll need a branch to fend it off.
TEGAN: A small tree wouldn’t hold that thing back. Come on! Please!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 31
DOCTOR: Where did I put those keys? (SLAPPING POCKETS) Must be somewhere. Ah...
TEGAN: Doctor, no!
DOCTOR: Here. Over here. See these?
DOCTOR: Like them? Yes? I thought you would.
TEGAN: Those aren’t the TARDIS keys?
DOCTOR: Just uncut spares. (TO TROLL) Yes, pretty, aren’t they?
TEGAN: So now what?
DOCTOR: He’s probably in pain. I need to examine him.
TEGAN: Look out!
DOCTOR: Ah... Dropped them.
TEGAN: Here. I’ve got them.
DOCTOR: Tegan, get back!
DOCTOR: Tegan!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 32
DOCTOR WHO: AND BACKS OFF.
SASHA: (OFF) Secure the circle! See it off!
DOCTOR: The mutant’s retreating. Tegan? Are you alright?
TEGAN: How do you think I am? (BEAT) Who are this lot?
DOCTOR: Security forces, by the look of them. I’1l handle it.
SASHA: (APPROACHING) Doctor? Tegan? Sasha Dialfa, Earth Free Media.
DOCTOR: The Press?
TEGAN: You know us?
SASHA: We have to get you out of here now. Ragnar?
RAGNAR: Please put these wristbands on.
DOCTOR: I don’t think so. Stay by me, Tegan.
SASHA: You’re coming with us!
DOCTOR: Yes, thank you for your offer, but that sort of bossy behaviour only makes me dig my heels in.
SASHA: This area isn’t safe.
DOCTOR: Really. That mutant creature we saw — it used to be human, didn? = at?
TEGAN: Human? !
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 33
DOCTOR: Its accelerated growth caused by Zygma radiation, yes? (DARKLY) And Weng-Chiang was the God of Abundance.
TEGAN: Weng-who?
SASHA: There’s a base beneath us. An experimental camp. But it’s shielded and we can’t infiltrate it.
DOCTOR: Has the Supreme Alliance of Eastern States declared war on the Icelanders yet? And Magnus Greel, my old “friend” Magnus, is he still Minister of Justice?
SASHA: We have to get you out. Before the patrols find us.
TEGAN: We’re looking for our friends.
RAGNAR: Nyssa and Turlough. Yes?
DOCTOR: Where are they?
RAGNAR: Sasha! The dogs are out!
SASHA: Put the bands on now! We’re leaving!
DOCTOR: Not until we find our friends!
SASHA: I said —
RAGNAR: They’re here!
TEGAN: Oh my — dingoes! Men like dingoes! Doctor, get back!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 34
DOCTOR: Curious. You’re quite right, Tegan, they do appear to be some sort of hybrid — (BITTEN BY DINGO SOLDIER) Aaah!
TEGAN: Doctor! (STRUGGLING WITH RAGNAR) They’ve got him! Let me help him —
RAGNAR: Put the band on.
TEGAN: Help him! Please!
TEGAN: You moron, you hit the Doctor!
SASHA: Too late, they’ve got him! Withdraw! Pull back! Home!
TEGAN: No!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 35
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 16: INT. SPACE STATION
TEGAN: Ugh! (PANIC) Where am I? What did you just do?!
SASHA: What a mess!
TEGAN: I just blinked, and I was here.
RAGNAR: It’s okay. The trans always disorients people the first time.
TEGAN: Those dingo-soldiers took the Doctor. Take us back. We have to find him!
SASHA: Give her something to calm her down, Ragnar. I’ve a report to file.
RAGNAR: You’re safe here. We’ll get the Doctor back, I promise.
TEGAN: You’d better. Where is this?
RAGNAR: Earth Media Monitoring Station. We call it the Correspondents’ Club.
TEGAN: Where’s the way out?
RAGNAR: There’s no way out. We’re in space, Tegan. In cloaked orbit two-fifty klicks above the Earth.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 36
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 17: INT. FINDECKER’S LAB
DOCTOR: (GROANS, COMING TO) Ohh, my shoulder.
CHOPS: Hit by your own troopers. We just fetched you in.
DOCTOR: Into where exactly?
CHOPS: Hurr.. The Chief’s after you. He hates bushwalkers on his patch... Strings ‘em up insides-out.
DOCTOR: Tell him I’1ll be delighted to speak to him... once you’ve untied me.
CHOPS: WHINES NERVOUSLY.
DOCTOR: This is him, I take it? The Chief?
CHOPS: We brought him, Chief. Only a bit damaged.
FINDECKER: If you’ve finished, Sergeant Chops, get out.
FINDECKER: You'd better be co-operative, or I'll just give you a number and be done with you. Where are you damaged?
DOCTOR: My shoulder. It’s what’s termed friendly fire. I’m the Doctor, by the way.
FINDECKER: Let me see.
DOCTOR: Ow!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 37
FINDECKER: A glancing burn. It will soon heal.
DOCTOR: And you are.. no, let me guess. You must be... Findecker! Yes? Quantum physicist, cyborg engineer extraordinaire...
FINDECKER: Sa Yy Findecker, Honorary Alumnus, Plaava Institute.
DOCTOR: And the discoverer of the double nexus particle. Your “magnificent” achievements echo throughout history. What on Earth are you doing here?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 38
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 18: INT. SPACE STATION
RAGNAR: Tegan, Sasha’s in editorial. She’ll let us know as soon as there’s [news] — What’re you doing, staring out of the window?
TEGAN: Just looking out at the Earth. I thought the snow would be white, but it’s grey. It covers half the planet.
RAGNAR: I thought you’d have retuned the glass. Here, let me —
RAGNAR: (TO GLASS) Show spyfeed.
RAGNAR: APPLAUSE FROM SPACEDROME CROWD [ITALICISED SECTIONS EXTRACTED FROM NEXT SCENE]
TEGAN: Hey, that’s TV!
RAGNAR: Intelligent glass. You use your finger to flick through.
TEGAN: So what’s this we’re watching?
RAGNAR: Direct video feed from Peking.
TEGAN: And this is worth spying on, why?
RAGNAR: The Icelandic Alliance has sent a delegation — that’s them arriving — to establish a new Trade Accord with the self-styled Supreme Alliance of Eastern States.
INGRID: (ON MIC) Thank you, High Minister, for your warm welcome — in
INGRID: every way! [On behalf of the Icelandic Alliance, I want to say how good it is to be here in Peking. We hope for great things. Two Alliances in One Accord. The re-forging of Earth! ]
INGRID: [FX: APPLAUSE. ]
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 39
TEGAN: Who’s she?
RAGNAR: Ingrid Bjarnsdottir, the Icelandic Commissioner.
TEGAN: Very teutonic. And the guy she’s meeting?
RAGNAR: That’s Magnus Greel, Justice Minister of the Supreme Alliance.
MAGNUS GREEL: (ON MIC) Thank you, Commissioner. [The big speeches will come later, but one thing I know. There is a unity coming. One Earth at the heart of the Empire. Great things for a great day! ]
MAGNUS GREEL: [FX: RIOTOUS APPLAUSE, TO FIT UNDER... ]
TEGAN: Oh, right. The Doctor mentioned him. He’s handsome enough.
RAGNAR: Everything he touches stinks. He has dodgy funding links to several off-Earth science faculties. His opponents have a habit of disappearing. He’s got more blood on his hands than a butcher’s boy.
TEGAN: Not a fan then?
RAGNAR: Look at him. Smug and self-satisfied, lapping up the applause. He’s a monster.
TEGAN: Wait a minute. The woman beside him, that looks like —
MAGNUS GREEL: (ON MIC) [Thank you. Thank you. But] none of this could have been achieved without the support of my office and, of course, my devoted bride-to-be. [Please, my dear, step forward —]
TEGAN: No.. no, it can’t be...!
RAGNAR: You recognise her?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 40
TEGAN: That’s my best friend. The one who’s missing. That’s — that’s [Nyssa! ]
MAGNUS GREEL: (ON MIC) [Step forward..] Nyssa!
MAGNUS GREEL: [FX: APPLAUSE]
MAGNUS GREEL: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 41

elements.text: PART TWO
NO REPRISE
SCENE 19: EXT. SPACEDROME COURTYARD
FX: FADE UP APPLAUSE FROM SPACEDROME CROWD

(ON MIC) Thank you, High Minister, for your warm welcome — in every way! On behalf of the Icelandic Alliance, I want to say how good it is to be here in Peking. We hope for great things. Two Alliances in One Accord. The re-forging of Earth!
FX: APPLAUSE.
(ON MIC) Thank you, Commissioner. The big speeches will come later, but one thing I know. There is a unity coming. One Earth at the heart of the Empire. Great things for a great day!
FX: RIOTOUS APPLAUSE
(ON MIC) Thank you. Thank you. But none of this could have been achieved without the support of my office and, of course, my devoted bride-to-be. Please, my dear, step forward. Step forward... Nyssa!
FX: APPLAUSE
(OFF-MIC. MODEST) Oh no. Really, Magnus. No.
(OFF-MIC) Just a few words, my dear. Please.
(ON MIC. EMBARRASSED) .. A great day indeed!
FX: POLITE APPLAUSE.
ON MIC) The lovely Nyssa, my friends. (HE KISSES HER
FX: THE CROWD GOES ‘AHHH’ AND APPLAUDS. GO DIRECTLY INTO:
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 42
SCENE 20: INT. SPACE STATION — MONITORING AREA
FX: ABRUPTLY FREEZE APPLAUSE FROM PREVIOUS SCENE. CLICK. HEARD
OVER MONITOR, APPLAUSE REWINDING BACKWARDS AT SPEED. CLICK AND PLAY, FROM END OF PART ONE:
(D, OVER MONITOR) Please, my dear, step forward —
(OVER MONITOR) No... no, it can’t be..!
(OVER MONITOR) You recognise her?
(OVER MONITOR) That’s my best friend. The one who’s missing. That’s — that’s Nyssa!
FX: RECORDING PAUSES.
That shouldn’t have been a surprise. We know Nyssa travelled with the Doctor. She must know Tegan too.
FX: RAGNAR SPOOLS HIGHSPEED THROUGH THE RECORDING FOR A SECOND.
She gets quite ratty about it. Here.
FX: WE CUT INTO THE TINNY RECORDING:
TEGAN (RECORDING) Oh, come on. Credit Nyssa with a bit of sense. She couldn’t
“marry” him anyway.
RAGNAR (RECORDING) Why not?
TEGAN (RECORDING) (FLUSTERED) She can’t. She just wouldn’t, that’s all.
RAGNAR (RECORDING) Magnus Greel has power and money.
TEGAN (RECORDING) You said he’s a monster! No. Nyssa wouldn’t.
RAGNAR (RECORDING) People change. When did you last see her?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 43
TEGAN (RECORDING) (AWKWARD) That’s not the easiest question to answer. How long’s she been here? When’s the wedding?
FX: RECORDING PAUSES.
She’s not making sense. She’s covering something up.
Then listen to the next bit.
FX: STARTS RECORDING.
TEGAN (RECORDING)
Now hang on. You’re not police, you’re reporters. How do I know you’re not setting Nyssa up? You could use this against her.
RAGNAR (RECORDING) You think she went into this with her eyes shut?
TEGAN (RECORDING) I don’t know why she did it. Is Magnus Greel really so bad?
RAGNAR (RECORDING) And you haven’t seen Nyssa for how long?
TEGAN (RECORDING) I never said.
RAGNAR (RECORDING) When we picked you up, you said you were looking for her.
TEGAN (RECORDING) Nyssa and Vislor Turlough. Have you got a file on him, too? And how about helping the Doctor?
FX: RECORDING STOPS
They must know about the base. Why else would they be in the Dead Zone?
It’s taken us three years to locate Greel’s facility, but the Doctor gets inside in five minutes flat.
If he wasn’t killed in the process. He’1ll be like the others. He won’t have lasted ten minutes. (FX: SHARP CUT TO:)
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 44
SCENE 21: INT. FINDECKER’S LAB
FX: A TEETH-JANGLING GRIND OF ELECTRIC BUZZING.
(GROANS) Findecker... Findecker.. is this really necessary?
Your genetic physiology is unusually elaborate. Certainly not human.
Look who’s talking. Wouldn’t this be easier over a cup of tea, not the operating table?
That precludes the principle that you might lie to me.
The very idea.
No. I prefer to work on my own terms. (HE TAKES A DEEP BREATH)
FX: A SMALL INSISTENT TWINKLING NOTE.
(SOOTHING HYPNOTIC) Listen to my words. You’re eager to tell me everything. Who you are. Why you are here. Begin.
Hypnosis? Sorry, that stage act won’t work on me.
FX: NOTE FADES.
Who are you? You cite my reputation. Yet my work is secret, unpublished.
My dear Findecker, your pioneering research is the talk of every faculty and student bar from Mars North to Goodweather Three. Everywhere I go, the buzz is “Double Nexus Particle.”
How do you know that?
It’s common knowledge. The Galaxy hangs on your every equation. I don’t suppose a small tour of your facility would be possible?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 45
You’re a liar, of course...
Oh, now just a minute.
. but a skilled one. Somehow you know my work. Even covet it, yes?
Well...
And I rarely converse with anyone remotely approaching my level of enquiring intelligence.
I know the feeling.
Alright. I’11 show you round, Doctor whoever-you-are...
Well, thank you.
But one illicit move and my guards will use all of their canine zeal to tear you into edible gobbets.
Understood. Magnus Greel is lucky to have so illustrious a scientist in his service.
I’m no lackey of Greel’s.
Of course not.
The man is a scientific ruffian.
But he has power.
Oh, he will have. But he’ll pay through the nose before I give it to him.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 46
SCENE 22: INT. GREEL’S SALOON (IN MOTION)
FX: GENTLE HUM OF THE ENGINE. OTHER CARS PASS.
So how was I?
(AMUSED) Very statesman-like.
Oh? Not presidential?
You're not even Commissioner yet. Besides, Presidents don’t devour their brides-to-be in public.
No? I thought Presidents did what they liked.
No.
How disappointing. I’d better resign and get a job on a guano dredger sifting the rings of Saturn. No-one knows or even cares what they get up to. (BEAT) Poor Nyssa. Will you miss me?
Perhaps. But the Icelandic Commissioner did not look amused.
It’s all that snow where she comes from. Brrrrr. No fire in the blood.
LAUGHS
Two hours at home and then off to the boring banquet.
Kaori will have laid out our clothes. She’s a wonderful present, Magnus. I love her head made of flowers. Thank you.
If it gives you more time for your projects.
It does. And I’d.. well, I’d wondered [if...]
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 47
Yes?
I’d like to see more of the factories.
Earth has precious little else to offer.
Perhaps I could make some visits? In an official capacity, of course.
Let me guess. You know more about the technology than I do.
Actually I meant to see the workers’ conditions.
Ah...
I hear stories about low credit and twenty-five hour work shifts. And poor health too.
That’s my little ex-medic speaking.
I hope so. I’d feel involved, Magnus.
Well... alright, I’1l sound out the Ministry. Just don’t interfere too much. (BEAT) Nearly home.
And also...
Yes.
I was checking through your finances... and I found some unexplained anomalies.
(TESTY) Nyssa...
Payments to an anonymous off-Earth account. Large amounts. Several million credits each time.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 48
(LAUGHING) Maybe you’re not supposed to know.
But I was concerned.
Oh, Nyssa. You found me out. (SIGH) Alright. If you must know. (LYING) It’s a trust I set up for us.
For us?
For our future children... once we’re married.
(AWKWARD) Ah...
But it’s a secret. So don’t tell them yet.
Right.
You know, perhaps it’s time we did something about [that.]
FX: DISTANT RAYGUN SHOT. CAR WINDOW IMPLODES.
HIT, GASPS AND SLUMPS
Nyssa!
FX: CAR SWERVES AND CRUNCHES TO A HALT. DISTANT SIRENS START TO
WAIL.
Get help, driver! Get help! (TENDERLY) Nyssa...
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 49
SCENE 23: INT. SPACE STATION
Look, I’m sick of this. All you people do is question me.
“Interview” you.
It feels like harassment.
Then suppose you try giving straight answers, Tegan.
No. You tell me for a change!
(BEAT) Go on then.
When you found the Doctor and me, you knew who we were.
We'd been expecting you for three years.
Three!
Ever since Nyssa and Vislor Turlough arrived on Earth.
That long ago! Were they hurt?
I was still a cub reporter. Sasha brought them in. Full interviews. Exclusives.
They were in shock. But they were adamant you’d come back for them one day.
They’ve been waiting for us? For three years?
They said the Doctor’s ship smashed into a time displacement beam...
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 50
Someone was working on time travel experiments, flinging victims back in time.
Thousands of bodies strewn across a mountain in snowy Bhutan. It was a massacre. But we were seeing the effect before the cause.
The morgue before the murder.
Oh, shut up.
It’s true. It took years tracing the beam back to the Dead zone.
Brisbane... that was my home once.
There’d been an energy spill, years back. The area was off limits.
The perfect spot to build a hidden base.
How “convenient.”
And Nyssa and Turlough?
When you traced that beam, you landed at the wrong end.
Oh, great.
Sasha found your friends stranded three years earlier at the target point, among the sea of corpses.
No ID. No credit. After the interviews, Editorial must have found placements for them.
In Peking?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page
Peking? Reykjavik?
I don’t know. We don’t get told.
Nyssa’s done well enough for herself.
And you’ve broadcast all this?
Not yet... It’s still on file.
The fact is.. we can’t go public. Not till we open up that base
and expose who’s behind it all.
But the Doctor’s already in there. Isn’t that enough proof?
I’ve filed a request with Editorial. Once they’ve stamped it,
in we go to find him.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 52
SCENE 24: INT. FINDECKER’S BASE — CORRIDOR
FX: METAL DOOR SLIDES OPEN.
(WALKING INTO CORRIDOR) Chops! Stop dawdling. Bring our guest.
Move on.
Sorry, Chops. (FX: THEY WALK) This base of yours really is bigger than it looks, Findecker.
We have three kilometres of cold storage areas.
Looks more like an abattoir. But the carcass racks are empty.
Oh, I never work on carcasses. Living tissue yields far better results. Regrettably, it has a much shorter shelf life.
Live humans die so easily, don’t they? Especially when exposed to high doses of Zygma radiation. That must be such a nuisance.
Fortunately Earth’s colonies are rich in supplies. I get regular deliveries.
Forgive me, but isn’t experimenting in time travel like shooting arrows at the sky? You never get them back, or see the results.
My subjects are projected into the past. That way the results are easily retrievable.
And what’s the survival rate? Not many, so I heard.
FX: FINDECKER SLIDES BACK A METAL DOOR.
Chops! Bring him through.
(TO DOCTOR) You. Onto balcony.
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 53
FX: THEY STEP OUT, ONTO A BALCONY. CONTINUES DIRECTLY INTO:
SCENE 25. EXT. FINDECKER’S BASE — BALCONY [CONTINUOUS]
What’s this?
A daily task. Chops! It’s feeding time.
FX: CHOPS BANGS A GONG REPEATEDLY. HOWL OF THE TROLL,
APPROACHING FROM BELOW.
Ah... that’1l be another of your experiments. Your pet troll? I think I met him earlier.
He’s more of a genetic side effect. Zygma radiation stimulated his growth hormone out of all expected proportion.
He grew and grew. And now he’s the biggest toddler in town.
He makes a good guard dog. And he’s delightfully aggressive when provoked. Chops? Attach the Doctor to the rail.
FX: TROLL MOANING DIRECTLY BENEATH.
Hands together.
FX: CHAINS CLINK AS HE MANACLES THE DOCTOR TO THE RAILING.
Ow! This really isn’t necessary, you know —
FX: FINDECKER BANGS THE GONG AGAIN.
Dangle him over the side, Chops. Let’s see how our giant little one responds to the stimulation of a new toy.
And I thought we were getting on so well — (SHOVED OVER RAILING) — aaah!

DOCTOR: Exactly. Sasha’s account of bodies dumped on a mountainside in Bhutan.
TEGAN: When she first met Nyssa and Turlough!
DOCTOR: All it tells us is that “Two unknowns were picked up.”
TEGAN: That’s all?
DOCTOR: Yes, and the visuals are restricted access.
TEGAN: Maybe they’re being sensitive.
DOCTOR: Yes... I wonder...
DOCTOR: FURIOUSLY AT IT. DOOR OPENS.
TEGAN: Oh look, another insomniac. What’s up, Ragnar?
RAGNAR: Editorial are not happy.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 97
TEGAN: Surely they can run an exposé on Greel by now.
RAGNAR: They want an exclusive on the Doctor.
DOCTOR: I don’t do interviews. (SEES SOMETHING WORRYING) Ah...
TEGAN: Find something?
DOCTOR: (COVERING UP) Erm, no. No, not exactly.
RAGNAR: Let’s see.
DOCTOR: Oops. Oh, sorry. Lost it.. Never mind, eh? It wasn’t important.
RAGNAR: (SUSPICIOUS) Right...
TEGAN: Why can’t Greel be arrested and tried as a war criminal?
RAGNAR: There isn’t a war.
DOCTOR: Not yet. But there soon will be.
RAGNAR: You think that’1l happen?
DOCTOR: Maybe. But Greel won’t be involved. He dies elsewhere. Not in this time.
TEGAN: Oh, here we go. This, Ragnar, is the most complicated man in the Universe.
DOCTOR: Thank you.
TEGAN: You know what’1ll happen, don’t you? Were you there?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 98
DOCTOR: No comment. I can try to minimise the damage, but I can’t stop Greel himself.
TEGAN: (PORTENTOUS) Not without messing up the fabric of time?
DOCTOR: It’s very delicate.
RAGNAR: So where does Greel die? And will it be horrible?
DOCTOR: (GRAVE) Ragnar... No-one should ever know that.
TEGAN: We could still pull Nyssa and Turlough out of Peking and leave.
DOCTOR: Without my TARDIS?
RAGNAR: Want to go down there?
DOCTOR: I thought you’d never ask.
RAGNAR: Right. It’s off your own back. It’1ll be news to me. I can’t think how you got hold of the wristband.
DOCTOR: Thank you. I’1ll take Chops too. He needs a walk.
RAGNAR: (LEAVING) Right.
TEGAN: Ready when you are.
DOCTOR: Erm, no Tegan.
TEGAN: Stay here? Oh, now come on.
DOCTOR: (CONFIDENTIAL) We won’t be long. Keep an eye on our friend Ragnar. And don’t let him do anything foolish.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 99
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 51: INT. GREEL’S HOUSE — RECEPTION
TURLOUGH: So who was this mystery intruder?
NYSSA: He said his name was Findecker, and that he works for my — (CATCHES HERSELF) — for Greel.
TURLOUGH: And he knows about us?
NYSSA: He knows everything. He was sitting there by the fire, Turlough. It was frightening.
TURLOUGH: But has he told Greel?
NYSSA: I don’t know. You didn’t see Magnus at the banquet. He went crazy. All because of that explosion. I never saw that coming. Not like that. He’s seriously disturbed.
TURLOUGH: We should have got out of here long ago.
NYSSA: But suppose Findecker is somehow causing it. Did you meet your contact?
TURLOUGH: He didn’t show.
NYSSA: He didn’t...?
TURLOUGH: There are new guards on the streets - all over town. So I went to the Embassy. I nearly got caught myself.
NYSSA: You saw Mrs Bjarnsdottir?
TURLOUGH: Briefly. She’s trapped as well. Those guards... They’re Greel’s private army. That’s what he’s investing in. He’s going to seize control. Nyssa.. she wants us to stay.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 100
NYSSA: To stay? Suppose I speak to Commissioner DuPlessis? Tell him everything. He could stop this.
GREEL: Nyssa?
NYSSA: (STARTLED) Oh! Magnus.
TURLOUGH: Good morning, Minister.
NYSSA: How did you sleep?
GREEL: (TO NYSSA) I don’t want him here anymore.
NYSSA: Magnus?
GREEL: I want him out!
NYSSA: Turlough is my private secretary.
GREEL: Is that all he is?
NYSSA: Magnus, that’s ridiculous.
TURLOUGH: Minister, I have every respect for your fiancée.
GREEL: Particularly behind my back!
GREEL: Get out!
NYSSA: No, Magnus!
GREEL: Out!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 101
TURLOUGH: (LEAVING) Sorry, Nyssa.
GREEL: Miss Traken to you! Soon to be Mrs Greel!
NYSSA: Magnus...
GREEL: (WEEPING) It’s all gone away.
NYSSA: Come on. Let’s get you some help. It’1ll be alright.
GREEL: No. Just you, Nyssa. You’re all I need to see. Just you...
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 102
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 52: EXT. PEKING MARKET
DOCTOR WHO: TELEPORT AS BEFORE.
DOCTOR: Here we are. How’s your sense of direction, Chopsy? Last time I was here, it was still Beijing.
CHOPS: (SNIFFS) Too many niffs in the air.
DOCTOR: No, maybe the market wasn’t the best place to land.
CHOPS: Hang on. (DEEP BREATH)
DOCTOR: What now?
CHOPS: Mark outs. (SNIFFING ROUND) Jumbuck... and Duster... and Jaywick...
DOCTOR: Friends of yours? Marking their territory?
CHOPS: But they’re for Greel. Not my new Chief.
DOCTOR: Stay upwind if you can. Come on.
CHOPS: Ah...
DOCTOR: Something else?
CHOPS: Not good. Know that niff. It’s Him. The old Chief.
DOCTOR: Findecker?
CHOPS: Stay close. We’ll soon track him down.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 103
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 53: INT. SPACE STATION
RAGNAR: (IN SHOCK) I don’t believe this.
TEGAN: Ragnar?
RAGNAR: I checked back over what the Doctor was viewing. I knew he was hiding something.
TEGAN: That’s Nyssa and Turlough!
SASHA: Are you hurt? Can you tell me where you came from? Look, I’d like to interview you.
RAGNAR: It’s Sasha’s last report. The restricted video. He got into it.
NYSSA: You’re Sasha?
TURLOUGH: There’s someone here who told us to expect you.
TEGAN: The Doctor sees that sort of thing as a challenge. Oh... they look so cold. Is this through Sasha’s eyes?
SASHA: Me?
NYSSA: He’s here. I’m sorry.
RAGNAR: POV Cams. Standard fitting.
TURLOUGH: We tried to help him, but...
RAGNAR: I can’t watch this.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 104
DOCTOR WHO: (STUNNED) Ragnar! Oh, my — His face. He’s so old. What
DOCTOR WHO: happened?
TEGAN: Ragnar?
RAGNAR: It’s me, but I wasn’t there. How was I there?
NYSSA: He said he came from the future.
TURLOUGH: Three years in the future.
TEGAN: Turn it off, Ragnar.
SASHA: He did it. He proved it. The idiot killed himself to prove it!
NYSSA: I’m sorry.
SASHA: (CRYING) The victims are coming from the future. Oh, [heavens-]
TEGAN: That’s enough.
RAGNAR: I looked so old. Like I was my granddad.
TEGAN: It doesn’t have to be that way.
RAGNAR: It hasn’t happened yet... but it will. I’m gonna be thrown back in time - back to then. And Editorial knew. That’s why they covered it up! The morgue before the murder - that’s what I said. And Sasha was there. She knew, and didn’t tell me! That must have broken her.
TEGAN: No. Things can be changed.
RAGNAR: Oh, yeah? Is that what your precious Doctor says? (GETTING UP) No, I’m TRANSing down now!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 105
TEGAN: It could be years yet, Ragnar. You’re not thinking straight. Just wait!
RAGNAR: Wait? How much time have I got? I can’t wait!
TEGAN: (FOLLOWING) Then I’m coming with you. We’1ll find the Doctor together!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 106
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 54: NYSSA’S ANSAFONE
NYSSA: Hello. I’m not here at the moment. Please leave a message.
TURLOUGH: (EXCITED BUT HAVING TO SPEAK FURTIVELY) Nyssa? It’s me. Nyssa, call me when you can. I’m in the outer office. I’ve just seen the TARDIS being wheeled in. Here, in the Ministry!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 107
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 55: EXT. PEKING STREET
DOCTOR WHO: APPEAR.
TEGAN: Woah. This is Peking, right?
RAGNAR: (CALMER, GRIMLY RESOLVED) That’s the Justice Ministry through the Pagoda Gate.
TEGAN: (SETTING OFF) Come on, Ragnar. We have to find the Doctor.
RAGNAR: No, Tegan. That’s your story. I have nothing to lose. I’ve just seen my own death.
TEGAN: But you might walk straight into it. Ever heard of a self- fulfilling prophecy?
RAGNAR: The sooner, the better.
TEGAN: No! Look, when they found you on the mountain, you looked old.
RAGNAR: All the bodies were old. It’s the time travel process. The radiation. But when I find Findecker and Greel...
TEGAN: But what if we can break the circle? Think, Ragnar. If you won’t do it for yourself, then do it for Sasha.
RAGNAR: The war sirens. It’s starting. Good luck, Tegan. Find the Doctor and get out while you can.
TEGAN: Ragnar! Wait!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 108
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 56: INT. JUSTICE MINISTRY — GREEL’S OFFICE
GREEL: (AT DESK, LOOKING UP) I said, I was not to be dist-[urbed] (BREAKS OFF) Findecker?!?
FINDECKER: You are surprised to see me in the Ministry?
GREEL: I’m surprised to see you at all! I thought... with the explosion...
FINDECKER: Yes, well — despite the efforts of some depressingly manic Time Agent, normal service, as they say, has been resumed.
GREEL: Time Agent-?
FINDECKER: Last night, plenty was lost. But more was gained. I bring you a gift, Greel. A trophy. (CLAPS HANDS, CALLING OFF) Workborgs! Bring in the box!
GREEL: Trophy? What sort of trophy is this?
FINDECKER: (TO ROBOTS) There, in the corner. (FX: ROBOTS PLACE THE TARDIS AND DEPART, THROUGH:) This, Greel, is the aforesaid Time Agent’s craft.
GREEL: (READING) “Police... Box.”
FINDECKER: Yes. It seems we are scrutinised by hitherto unknown authorities. We must be alert.
GREEL: You mean, there could be more of these ‘Time Agents’?.
FINDECKER: If one is here, more may follow. And you, Greel?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 109
GREEL: Me? I am summoned to the Commissioner’s office. But the old fool can wait. My guards... our guards surround the Icelandic Embassy. I have demands to issue. Cases to review. Sentences to pass. (LAUGHING) Business as usual.
FINDECKER: And your lovely bride-to-be?
GREEL: Nyssa? (RELAXES) What would I do without her? She is my salvation.
FINDECKER: I assumed that was me. Oh dear, Magnus. I fear I must disabuse you of that notion.
GREEL: Do what? I don’t understand.
FINDECKER: Kaori!
KAORI: I am ready, sir.
FINDECKER: The list of Nyssa’s misdemeanours as you have observed them.
GREEL: Her what?
FINDECKER: Please begin.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 110
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 57: EXT./INT. JUSTICE MINISTRY
DOCTOR: (EFFORTFUL) I’ve often wondered, Chops, why it is that windows are never left open on the ground floor? — (SNAGGED) Ow!
CHOPS: (BELOW) There’s a door down here.
DOCTOR: What? Ouch!
TURLOUGH: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Turlough! It’s you!
TURLOUGH: I don’t believe it, after all this [time] — (BREAKS OFF) What are you doing, climbing up the wall of the Justice Ministry?
DOCTOR: Explanations later, but first — this wisteria isn’t very sturdy, so if you would...?
TURLOUGH: Here, let me help you.
DOCTOR: (SLIPPING) Agh!
TURLOUGH: It’s alright, I’ve got you. Hold on. In you come...
DOCTOR: (JUMPING DOWN ONTO FLOOR) Oof! Thank you, Turlough. Just a moment. (CALLS DOWN) Chops. Stay out of sight. Be with you in minute.
CHOPS: (BELOW) Gotcha, Chiefy.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 111
TURLOUGH: So where have you been the last three years?
DOCTOR: It may not feel like it, Turlough, but we came straight away. What about Nyssa? Is she really engaged to Magnus Greel?
TURLOUGH: It’s a long story. I’m her secretary. Or was, until this morning.
DOCTOR: Turlough, Greel is one of the worst maniacs in Earth’s sorry history. I only hope Nyssa knows just what a dangerous game she’s playing.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 112
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 58: INT. JUSTICE MINISTRY — GREEL’S OFFICE
KAORI: [..] May fourth: Nyssa passes restricted data to Mr Turlough, who conveys it to the Icelandic Embassy. May eighth: Mr Turlough supplies Nyssa with data pertaining to the Minister’s private financial investments. May twentieth:
GREEL: (STUNNED) That’s enough! Findecker, I can hardly believe this!
FINDECKER: Under your own roof, Greel. Clearly you were too busy to notice.
GREEL: Kaori! Where is Nyssa? Fetch her now!
KAORI: Nyssa is no longer in the Ministry.
GREEL: Then find her! And her “secretary”!
RAGNAR: Greel! Magnus Greel1!
GREEL: Who are you? How did you get in here-?
RAGNAR: Press pass. Down on the floor, you murderer!
FINDECKER: I know this man.
RAGNAR: You too, Findecker!
FINDECKER: This is one of the... ruffians who destroyed my project.
RAGNAR: On the floor! Or I’11l shoot your alien kneecaps out!
FINDECKER: (COLD) I will not bow to you. Or your like. Kaori...?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 113
KAORI: The use of a gun in the Ministry is forbidden.
FINDECKER: Thank you, Kaori.
GREEL: (FX: FLICKS COMMS) Security! In here now! (FX: DISTANT ALARM SOUNDS )
FINDECKER: Wait. My old workshop here is still viable. I mean to recommence my research. This one can be my first subject.
GREEL: Legally sentenced first, Findecker! Let’s do it properly. Star Chamber sits in thirty minutes.
GREEL: Guards — arrest this man. Charge him with the attempted murder of a government official. Tab scan for record, motives and ID. He is already pronounced guilty.
RAGNAR: (COMING ROUND) Wh-what...?
GREEL: Take him down. You others — bring the Time Agent’s craft!
GREEL: INTO:
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 114
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 59: INT. JUSTICE MINISTRY — CORRIDOR/CUPBOARD
DOCTOR: Was it worth it, Turlough? Working for the Icelanders?
TURLOUGH: (MUTTER) Keep it down, Doctor. Guards everywhere. (FX: OPENING DOOR) In here.
DOCTOR: A stationery cupboard?!?
TURLOUGH: (GRABBING DOCTOR) Just get in!
TURLOUGH: You must realise, Doctor — the Icelanders had to know what Greel was planning.
DOCTOR: And Nyssa thought it was the right thing to do?
TURLOUGH: She didn’t mean to land up engaged.
DOCTOR: I’m sure she didn’t.
TURLOUGH: But Greel can be charm on a stick when he likes.
DOCTOR: Not the insane, craven monster he’1l become, then. Where is Nyssa now?
TURLOUGH: She’s gone.
DOCTOR: What?
TURLOUGH: Gone to the Commissioner’s office to expose Greel for the villain he is. And get him arrested. (BEAT) Well, we had to do something!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 115
DOCTOR: But that’s not Greel’s fate. We have to stop [her.]
TURLOUGH: (WHISPER) Sh! Someone’s outside. One of Greel’s dingo soldiers.
CHOPS: (FROM BEHIND DOOR) Chief? You in there?
DOCTOR: It’s alright, he’s with me. (FX: OPENS DOOR) Chops! You gave us a fright.
CHOPS: Got tired of waiting. And then...
TEGAN: . then he picked up a scent he recognised.
TURLOUGH: Tegan?
TEGAN: Turlough. Oh, it’s great to see you. (HUGS HIM)
TURLOUGH: (BEING HUGGED) It’s, er, good to see you too.
DOCTOR: Tegan, I told you to stay put.
TEGAN: Ragnar found out about Sasha.
DOCTOR: Ah...
TEGAN: He totally freaked. I couldn’t stop him. He came down here to sort Greel out.
DOCTOR: Oh, good grief.
TURLOUGH: Hang on. Is this Ragnar Crezzen, hothead reporter? Trying to face off Magnus Greel?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 116
TEGAN: With a gun. We have to stop him. Or he’1l land up dead on a mountain three years ago!
DOCTOR: Tegan.
TEGAN: No! Don’t tell me it can’t be changed!
DOCTOR: I can’t be everywhere. I have to stop Nyssa!
TEGAN: Nyssa?
DOCTOR: Her best intentions could throw the whole of Earth’s future history into chaos!
TEGAN: I don’t believe this. Will you stop holding Time’s hand for just one minute? It’s bigger than you are. It can look after itself. We’re talking about people here with hopes and rights. Maybe, left alone, they can change it for the better by themselves!
TEGAN: SCENE 60: INT. COURTROOM
GREEL: Ragnar Crezzen, you are found guilty of the attempted murder of a government official of the Supreme Alliance of Eastern States.
RAGNAR: (QUIETLY) People have to know.
STEWARD: Quiet.
GREEL: The subversive actions of Earth Free Media have imperilled the security of the Alliance. Such crimes are punishable by termination.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 117
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 61: INT. OUTSIDE COURTROOM
DOCTOR: (HUSHED) People are leaving.
STEWARD: (DISTANT) This session of Star Chamber is now closed.
CHOPS: (HUSHED) Too late.
TEGAN: (HUSHED) We’ve missed Ragnar?
TURLOUGH: (HUSHED) He’1ll have been sent down. Sorry, Tegan.
TEGAN: I’m not giving up yet. Where will they take him?
STEWARD: (APPROACHING) Please clear the court.
TURLOUGH: Excuse me. These people are guests of the Minister.
STEWARD: The Minister was leaving. And animals are not allowed.
CHOPS: Who’s an animal?
DOCTOR: Oh, how very tiresome. Magnus promised to see us.
TEGAN: We’ve come all the way from Queensland.
TURLOUGH: He must have forgotten. But erm.. (FX: RUSTLES MONEY) .. if you let us through we might still catch him.
STEWARD: (TAKING MONEY) That will do nicely, Mr Turlough. Third door on the left.
TURLOUGH: Thanks. Come on, you lot.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 118
TEGAN: (DEPARTING) How much did you pay him, Turlough?
DOCTOR: (DEPARTING) The joys of Baksheesh.
STEWARD: (CALLING AFTER) Better hurry. The Minister was in a rush.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 119
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 62: INT. COMMISSIONER DUPLESSIS’S OFFICE
NYSSA: Commissioner DuPlessis?
DUPLESSIS: (AWKWARD) Nyssa...
NYSSA: Please excuse this intrusion, but I have to speak with you.
DUPLESSIS: (PANICKY) My dear, it’s not convenient. —
NYSSA: It’s about Greel. Commissioner, I have proof that he plans to seize control of the Alliance. He’s working with an alien scientist called Findecker.
DUPLESSIS: (SADLY) Oh, Nyssa...
GREEL: (FROM OFF) What did I tell you, Commissioner?
NYSSA: Magnus! I — I didn’t see you there...
GREEL: Evidently, or you would not have shown your true colours. (STANDING, STRIDING TOWARDS NYSSA) All the time we’ve been together, you were in the pay of the Icelandic Alliance. Gaining my trust, passing secrets. Living lies! (GROWING MANIC) You affect the air of a self-righteous do-gooder, the perfect Ministerial consort! But you’re a cheat and a liar! (TWISTING NYSSA’S ARM) And we all know what happens to liars, don’t we?
NYSSA: (SCARED) My arm, Magnus! You’re hurting me...!
DUPLESSIS: Leave her be, Minister.
GREEL: You dare to oppose me, Commissioner, knowing how much you stand to lose?
DUPLESSIS: Time travel? Hasn’t that fool’s gold has caused enough deaths already? It isn’t worth it.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 120
GREEL: You’re the fool!
DUPLESSIS: Your ambition has no limits, Magnus. But it’s all about you, not the Alliance. It has to end here.
DUPLESSIS: Security! In here please.
DUPLESSIS: What’s this? What are these creatures?
NYSSA: (REALISATION) No, Magnus! You mustn’t-!
GREEL: My guards, DuPlessis! Not yours. Your days are over.
DUPLESSIS: (NERVOUSLY) Call them off.
NYSSA: Please, Magnus! Call them off!
GREEL: If the Alliance doesn’t want my leadership... I’1l sell myself elsewhere. Come on, Nyssa!
NYSSA: No!
DUPLESSIS: Security! Security! Answer!
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 121
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 63: INT. FINDECKER’S LAB
FINDECKER: . Prisoner “One Zero Zero, Seven Four Two” - because that’s all you are now. It’s too late for vengeance, I’m afraid.
RAGNAR: I knew that.
FINDECKER: But you’re still an invaluable part of my research. So thank you, Ragnar Crezzen. Your circle is complete.
DOCTOR: (RUSHING IN) Turn off the chamber, Findecker!
FINDECKER: You! How did you get in here?
TEGAN: Turn it off!
DOCTOR: Out of my way!
DOCTOR: POWERS DOWN.
FINDECKER: Guards! G— (MUFFLED)
CHOPS: (STIFLING FINDECKER) Keep it quiet, Chiefy!
TEGAN: Ragnar’s still here! He didn’t get sent!
DOCTOR: Turlough, help me get him out of there. (FX: HE & TURLOUGH RELEASING RAGNAR FROM CHAMBER THROUGH: )
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 122
TEGAN: We stopped you, Findecker. We changed Time! The circle’s broken!
FINDECKER: Interfering dullards!
CHOPS: Quiet.
TURLOUGH: Doctor? Is Ragnar alright? He’s not moving.
TEGAN: Oh, no...
TURLOUGH: Look at his face. It’s withered, just like it was on the mountain.
DOCTOR: He’s still breathing. But the Zygma beam has had its effect. We may have broken the loop and changed time. But at what cost?
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 123
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 64: INT. ICELANDIC EMBASSY
INGRID: Who’s there?
GREEL: Good afternoon, Ingrid.
INGRID: Magnus Greel? This is intolerable. When will my Embassy staff be released?
GREEL: I came personally to apologise.
INGRID: You expect me to believe that? After last night?
GREEL: An unfortunate aberration.
INGRID: You insulted the Icelandic Alliance.
GREEL: And I am duly contrite. I see you still have our gift. I hope he’s behaving.
INGRID: I demand a public apology.
GREEL: Of course. Of course. But as you’1ll appreciate, in this unstable political climate, I find I must offer my services to the most reliable employers.
INGRID: Minister Greel. We are hostages to your dog-brained guards.
GREEL: Your embassy is under my protection, Commissioner.
GREEL: Accept my services and I promise you and your staff safe passage home to Reykjavik. Nyssa and I shall accompany you.
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 124
INGRID: Nyssa?
GREEL: Of course. I know she was your agent, Ingrid.
INGRID: As long as we know where we stand.
GREEL: Besides, I have another gift for you.
INGRID: Another dancing doll? This is laughable. I know what you want. You want asylum!
GREEL: What I offer you will give the Icelandic Alliance supreme power over its opponents. The last enigma. The prize of time travel.
INGRID: (ASTONISHED) Then... the rumours are true!
GREEL: You see, Commissioner, you can hardly refuse.
SIN: END OF PART THREE
DOCTOR WHO: THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 125

elements.text: PART FOUR
NO REPRISE
SCENE 65: INT. FINDECKER’S LAB
Ragnar? How are you feeling?
(WEARY) Why did you pull me out of the machine?
We couldn’t let you go.
But Sasha’s at the other end.
Sasha? Sasha Dialfa?
That was three years ago.
She finds me on the mountain. It’s my deathwish, not yours.
sorry.
(ASIDE) Doctor, a word?
Turlough?
It is him - the man Nyssa and I found in the snow. The one who died.
That doesn’t happen anymore. We’ve changed the timeline - apparently.
(STILL HELD BY CHOPS) Is that what you Time Agents do? Change history?
Not usually, no. (BEAT) So what else do you have in this workshop of yours, Findecker?
THE BUTCHER OF BRISBANE by Marc Platt (FINAL) Page 126
Nothing that’s any concern of yours —
FX: DOCTOR SWISHES BACK A DRAPE.
Well, now. Who’d have thought it? Magnus Greel’s original Time
Cabinet. How about that!
It is mine. Not Greel’s.
Beautifully rendered and lacquered. What a lovely object. Parallax synchrons. Intricate trionic lattice.
Don’t touch!
But still with the old Zygma problem. Eating away at the metabolism of its creator. Driving you to kill more and more to survive.
FX: COMM BUZZES.
I’ll get that, shall I?
(STRUGGLING) Give me that!
You stay where you are, old Chiefy!
FX: DOCTOR CLICKS ON COMMS.
I’m sorry. Mr Findecker isn’t available at the moment...
(D) Who in Hades...?
